title: Can a hyena kill a bear? - Quora

response.answer_text: Certainly, anything is possible, but a single hyena killing a bear on it’s own is very unlikely. Because: Bears, even young bears, are much larger than hyenas, and can withstand much more powerful blows than hyenas.Bears kill by grabbing (bear hug ?) and striking with their forearms, and biting. A single well - placed blow could kill an average hyena.Hyenas kill by inficting many, many bites, after chasing/harrassing their prey to the point of exhaustion. Often hyenas’ prey are bleeding and their guts hanging out from hyenas’ bites when they finally collapse. A single hyena could never accomplish such a feat with a bear unless the bear were disabled or greatly comprimised already.Hyenas very rarely hunt and kill alone. They are pack animals. Almost never 1 on 1.Bears often hunt and kill alone. Grizzly bears have been filmed chasing, catching, killing, and eating prey as large as full grown buffalos alone.It is unfathomable that a healthy bear would run from a single hyena. Much more likely is the bear, once it realizes the hyena is actually trying to hurt him, faces the hyena, charges, clamps his huge jaws down on the hyena’s head and crushes the life out of him. Then, casually tosses him aside. Done.Still, ……anything is possible. Bet on the bear, though.

No. They can't kill a male lion, so they can't kill a bear which is bigger. It takes a whole clan of hyenas to take on a male lion. Hyenas are strong animals and successful apex predators, but male lions are bigger and stronger than female spotted hyenas.

Hyenas weight 80 kg average while even the smallest bears (sloth bears) are almost twice of that weight, they are covered in deep layers of fat stored by overeating, they have 7–10 inch claws and huge canines, bears are much more equipped for fighting, hyenas are dogs with no claws and and powerful bites.
